Hi J.B.,

As Agitar's co-founder and CTO, I always hesitate to jump into product
discussions in this forum; but in this case it might be useful to
clarify some things. Especially since the discussion seems to be
quite civilized so far :-).

>so my opinion is largely
>theoretical in nature at present.

Thank you for recognizing that, but I can see how (based on the brief
description of our pricing model) you would reach your conclusions -
so we have to fix that and be clearer.

In practice, the number of classes on which the license is based is
measured more in orders or magnitudes than an very precise class
count. Many of our licenses are actually enterprise-wide and for an
unlimited number of users or classes. In all cases, there is ample
head-room for adding new classes and refactoring big-old-nasty
classes. As a matter of fact, one of the top uses for our JUnit
generation is to help create a safety net for working with legacy
code; and class/method refactoring is one of the things that we
recommend. You can see me giving a demo of exactly that type of
refactoring (at the method level) at:

http://www.agitar.com/solutions/products/agitarone_demos.html

(It's the first of the four mini-demos on that page ... No making fun
of my accent please, and NO we did not hire Borat to do the voice over
:-)).

Every pricing scheme has advantages and disadvantages. Most of us
want to move away from per-seat licensing. I believe that a
server-based solution with an unlimited number of classes (or with a
very generous over-allotment for growth and refactoring) is a step in
the right direction, but we are open to exploring other suggestions
(like the one you already made).

Thanks,

Alberto
